Merge pull request #306 from chris-morgan/whitelist-abbr-and-various-other-inline-semantic-elements

Whitelist various inline semantic/formatting tags

Whitelist various inline semantic/formatting tags

Mostly I want <abbr>, but the rest of these should also be whitelisted.

What goes in LIMITED.elements seems to be a bit subjective, but I think
that <mark> and <abbr> at least are reasonably justified. <dfn> is
fairly obscure, and <small>, <bdo>, <cite>, <span>, <time> and <wbr> a
bit different from the rest and probably not justified, so I left them
out.

In the absence of styling, <span> is quite useless, but <div>â€™s there
already, and people have asked for <span> (#183), so I figured, why not?

Fixes #183.

Merge pull request #304 from jetpackworkflow/allow_commonmarker_unsafe_option

Adds `UNSAFE` option to CommonMarker usage where needed

Adds `UNSAFE` option to CommonMarker usage where needed

With the [release of commonmarker
0.18.0](https://github.com/gjtorikian/commonmarker/releases/tag/v0.18.0),
HTML safety was introduced as a default (to avoid XSS).  But if someone
_wants_ to allow unsafe elements in their markdown, they should be able
to pass that option down to CommonMarker through html-pipeline.

Merge pull request #299 from stanhu/sh-freeze-all-the-things

Freeze all elements in HTML::Pipeline::SanitizationFilter

Freeze all elements in HTML::Pipeline::SanitizationFilter

We were recently burned by a regression that caused an exponential
number of transformers to be added to the pipeline because we didn't do
a deep copy of the whitelist. If these constants had been frozen, we
would have detected the error earlier.

Merge pull request #295 from ianks/fix-syntax-hl

Ensure <pre> nodes are not removed after syntax highlighting

Ensure <pre> nodes are not removed after syntax highlighting

After upgrading to rouge, I noticed the syntax highlighting in `octodown` has
disappeared. It seems that the `pre` tags were being removed, which are
neccesary for correct highlighting with rouge. This commit fixes this by
replacing the `inner_html` of the preblock with the code highlighted by rouge.

Merge pull request #268 from charliesome/ruby-2.4

Ruby 2.4
don't build rails 3 and rails 4 on ruby 2.4.0

bump github-linguist dependency to work around transitive dep issues

github-linguist 2.12.0 depends on an old version of pygments.rb which
depends on an old version of yajl-ruby which does not compile on ruby 2.4

only downcase ascii characters on ruby 2.4+

Starting in Ruby 2.4, the String case conversion methods are Unicode
aware. To ensure that anchors in TOC links remain stable when upgrading
to Ruby 2.4, we need to preserve the old behaviour by passing :ascii
to String#downcase

Merge pull request #257 from jch/bump-rails-dependency

Bump Active Support dependency to version >= 2
Exclude impossible builds to save CPU time

Don't pack unnecessary files to released gem

Rationale: https://github.com/bundler/bundler/pull/3207

39KB => 29KB

Avoid use of try, use respond_to? instead

Because Rails 3's `try` method behavior does not dance with its
successors:

Rails 3:

"".try(:call)
=> NoMethodError: undefined method `call' for "emoji":String

Rails 4+:

"".try(:call)
=> nil
Setup Appraisals and update .travis.yml
Bump Activesupport dependency to version >= 2
Release v2.4.2

Make Emoji img attributes configurable 1. User can specify a hash `context[:img_attrs]` to change the `img` tag attributes, e.g. `{ "draggable" => false }` 2. The hash key can be either `String` / `Symbol` (indifferent access) `{ "draggable" => false }` / `{ draggable: false }` => `` 3. The hash value can be either anything / proc-like object Proc-like object with default argument `name`: Given name is `:shipit:` `{ title: ->(name) { |n| n.gsub(":", "") } }` => `` So you can do any customisations with the attribute. 4. The hash value nil means clear the attribute of img tag For example, to clear the default `height`, `width`, and `align` attributes, pass `{ height: nil, width: nil, align: nil }` to `context[:img_attrs]`. 5. Refine tests with consistent styles

Manually merge pull request #126 from minitest

Replace Test::Unit With Minitest
- Squashed exploratory commits

Replace Test::Unit With Minitest

- Add minitest dependency to Gemfile test group
- Refactor `TestHelpers` and mixin to `Minitest::Test`
  - Remove unused `assert_doesnt_include`
  - Remove `assert_include` since `Minitest` defines `assert_includes`
- Replace `Test::Unit` methods with matching `Minitest` methods
- Refactor `assert_nothing_raised` to use `assert_equal` since
  `Minitest` doesn't define `assert_nothing_raised`
  - See http://blog.zenspider.com/blog/2012/01/assert_nothing_tested.html
- Add Travis CI build matrix
  - Allow REE to fail since charlock_holmes isn't installing
  - Fast finish so build doesn't wait for REE to fail

Remove RUBY_VERSION conditionals from gemspec

Remove the useless conditionals added in ae1f3c828cccd2b5ebf0678ea3edc2bcca10c9f3
since gemspec is turned into a static one at gem publish time, so the
version constraints will be adjusted to whatever Ruby version the gem
was *published* with, not the one that will eventually run the gem.

If someone is still running Ruby 1.8 or 1.9.2, it's their responsibility
to adjust their project's Gemfile to prevent Nokogiri or Active Support
upgrading to an incompatible version.

Feature-detect gemoji v2 on load time, not runtime

Allows subclasses to augment:

- EmojiFilter#emoji_filename(name)

Merge pull request #98 from aroben/configurable-schemes

Allow customization of allowed <a href> URL schemes

Allow specifying anchor schemes in the whitelist itself

If context[:anchor_schemes] is not passed, we use the schemes that are
specified in the whitelist itself. This matches our behavior from before
:anchor_schemes was added.

If :anchor_schemes is passed, it overrides any schemes specified in the
whitelist.

Add a test for SanitizationFilter::ANCHOR_SCHEMES

Clients may come to rely on this, so we should have a test to ensure we
don't break them.

Allow customization of allowed <a href> URL schemes

A new context parameter, :anchor_schemes, can be used to override the
default list of allowed schemes.

Note that this means that these schemes are no longer configurable via
the :whitelist context parameter. They can only be controlled via
:anchor_schemes.

Merge pull request #92 from jayroh/cgi-escape-emoji-name

CGI.escape emoji name

CGI.escape emoji name

The commonly used `+1`, when located somewhere like S3, will not work
as the + is not escaped, causing the browser to think it's a space
instead of a literal `+`. To replicate, upload +1.png to S3 and try to
bring it up in Chrome.

This commit escapes the emoji name before returning the img tag.

Clarify state handling in GitHub::HTML::Pipeline

Previously we were jumping through hoops to manage initial context
created with a pipeline, and then context that is passed in for
every `call` of a pipeline.  It was nasty, error prone, and I didn't
see a case where we were clearing out old state from previous runs
of pipeline.

Here I'm introducing a `default_context` which is passed to the
creation of a Pipeline, and the normal `context` that is passed into
call.  `default_context` gets merged onto `context`, so it always
wins, and both are frozen so they cannot be changed once set.

It still feels kinda crummy that we reuse these Pipeline instances
for our processing, as we don't have a good assurance that state
  is cleaned up between runs.  We basically have to very carefully
  code for it, hence the gradual move over time to freeze things like
  Result and context.

whitelist <div> through sanitization filter

No idea how this has never come up before. Literal <div>s are
perfectly legal markdown and cause the containing markup not to be
processed as markdown. Looks like we're stripping them in
sanitization here though which would cause a bunch of problems.

I'm whitelisting for other reasons: HTML email often include <div>s
and we need to retain them for proper layout in discussions.
Hopefully this won't cause problems elsewhere.

Bringing back the explicit range-dot regex

This reverts 32f7672 and 755df65.

Tighter regexes are awesome, but not at the expense of correct
functionality. @bkeepers pointed out we probably don't want to SHA-link
something like `somesubdomain.abcd0123.com`, and I agree with him.

Now there's a test that supports this, but there's just one. If there
are other SHA-like things we definitely want to not turn into SHA links,
we should make sure there are tests to cover those cases.

Commit-matching regexes get even tighter

Do you know what's cool? Word boundaries. Cooler than substituting some
text with itself.

Tighter regex for dot-led SHAs

@bkeepers mentioned it could be just `\.{2}` because the range regex
matches the ..., and then I noticed a single dot would do. Into the
character class with you!

Leave link URLs using the input SHAs

No need to be clever with shortening the SHAs used to make these links.
I was actually just about to pull this shortening behavior into the
regular commit-linking method (`replace_bare_commit_mentions`), but
decided instead to go the other way and take what was used as input,
only shortening the display text.

Test for commit range with invalid SHA.

This and the test to not link a range using .. seem a little off to me.
Should we still link these to individual commits? Maybe so if at least
part of it is a valid SHA. It seems more likely that someone is
accidentally hitting on range-ish syntax (by
typing..something..like...this) than valid SHAs.

Only linking ranges using ...

The comparison only works with the symmetric difference (...), not the
exclusionary thing (..). So don't try to make compare links using it.

Don't link ranges with invalid commits

And now finally this method looks pretty close to the others, with
getting the commit reference from the SHA, ensuring everything is
valid, and using the short SHA.

And there are tests to prove it works.

Better compare linking with long SHAs

Transforming nasty-long SHAs for comparison ranges into their shorter
counterparts, much like what happens with the single-commit links.

Also ensuring the linking works with either .. or ...

Autolinking sha ranges to compare view

Autolinking both the first and second commits in a range is cool, but
as @rtomayko pointed out, linking to the compare is awesome.

Autolink the second sha in a commit range

When someone comments with a range of shas, we auto link the first commit, but not the second (http://cl.ly/3z0O0g1o1s0I3T1Y0t0e). This fixes that by allowing a bar sha to be prefixed by one or two dots.

Ensure that HTML::Filter works on Strings

Some pipeline filters may perform on-place replacements
on strings. These replacements fail when the Filter has been initialized
with an `.html_safe` buffer (ActiveState::SafeBuffer).

Ensure that the string that is stored in the Filter state is always a
plain string.

Enable :lax_htmlblock when parsing MD Although the MD standard specifies that inline HTML blocks must be surrounded by blank lines before and after the block, the Markdown.pl parser does not honor this. We use the `lax_htmlblock` flag to mimic the output of the official parser, so now blocks like This is a paragraph 
		this is an inline html block
This is another paragraph are considered inline blocks.
